oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Optimizing BIKE for the Intel Haswell and ARM Cortex-M4
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chen, Ming-Shing
Chou, Tung
Krausz, Markus
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: constant-time implementations
NIST PQC standardization
Cortex-M4
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: BIKE is a key encapsulation mechanism that entered the third round of the NIST post-quantum cryptography standardization process. This paper presents two constant-time implementations for BIKE, one tailored for the Intel Haswell and one tailored for the ARM Cortex-M4. Our Haswell implementation is much faster than the avx2 implementation written by the BIKE team: for bikel1, the level-1 parameter set, we achieve a 1.39x speedup for decapsulation (which is the slowest operation) and a 1.33x speedup for the sum of all operations. For bikel3, the level-3 parameter set, we achieve a 1.5x speedup for decapsulation and a 1.46x speedup for the sum of all operations. Our M4 implementation is more than two times faster than the non-constant-time implementation portable written by the BIKE team. The speedups are achieved by both algorithm-level and instruction-level optimizations.
